Publications

Highlights

(For a full list see below or go to Google Scholar)

Forearc carbon sink reduces long-term volatile recycling into the mantle

We have demonstrated that a previously uinrecognized microbial sink is trapping substantial amounts of deep carbon in the forearc instead of escaping through volcanoes or sinking into Earth’s interior

Barry PH, JM de Moor, D Giovannelli, M Schrenk, D Hummer, T Lopez, CA Pratt, Y Alpízar Segura, A Battaglia, P Beaudry, G Bini, M Cascante, G d’Errico, M di Carlo, D Fattorini, K Fullerton, E Gazel, G González, SA Halldórsson, K Iacovino, JT Kulongoski, E Manini, M Martínez, H Miller, M Nakagawa, S Ono, S Patwardhan, CJ Ramírez, F Regoli, F Smedile, S Turner, C Vetriani, M Yücel, CJ Ballentine, TP Fischer, DR Hilton & KG Lloyd. 2019. Forearc carbon sink reduces long-term volatile recycling into the mantle. Nature,. 10.1038/s41586-019-1131-5

Living at the Extremes: Extremophiles and the Limits of Life in a Planetary Context

We compiled the current knowledge on the limit of life and tried to place it in planetary context, looking at what we might learn from Earth based life while searching for life on other planetary bodies.

Merino N, Aronson HS, Bojanova D, Feyhl-Buska J, Wong ML, Zhang S, Giovannelli D. 2019. Living at the Extremes: Extremophiles and the Limits of Life in a Planetary Context. Frontiers in Microbiology, accepted. 10.3389/fmicb.2019.00780

Metal Availability and the Expanding Redox Network of Microbial Metabolism in the Archean Eon

A discussion of the relationship between metal utilization in metabolism and the evolution of different metabolic pathways through time. We also attempt to reconstruct the wiring diagram of Earth’s geobiochemical cycles at different timepoint during our planet evolutionary history.

Moore E, Jelen B, Giovannelli D, Raanan H and Falkowski P. 2017. Metal Availability and the Expanding Redox Network of Microbial Metabolism in the Archean Eon. Nature Geoscience, 10: 629–636. 10.1038/ngeo3006

From extreme environments to human pathogens: an evolutionary journey

In this brif perspective I discuss together with Costa Vetriani the link between extremophiles, especially the Epsilonproteobacteria, and human pathogens, and how we can used comparative evolutionary genomic to study the evolutionary transition from free-living to obbligate pathogen.

Giovannelli D and Vetriani C. 2017. From extreme environments to human pathogens: an evolutionary journey. The Biochemist, vol. 39:6.

A Review of the Geochemistry and Microbiology of Marine Shallow-water Hydrothermal Vents

We reviewed our current knowledge regarding the geochemistry and the microbiology of shallow-water hydrothermal vents, highliting knowledge gaps and opportunities.

Price RE and Giovannelli D. 2017. A Review of the Geochemistry and Microbiology of Marine Shallow-water Hydrothermal Vents. Reference Module in Earth Systems and Environmental Sciences. 10.1016/B978-0-12-409548-9.09523-3

Insight into the evolution of microbial metabolism from the deep-branching bacterium, Thermovibrio ammonificans

Microbes that live in deep-sea hydrothermal vents offer a window into how early organisms survived on a young Earth. We used phylometabolic approaches to reconstruct the ancestral and acquired metabolism in the Aquificae phylum

Giovannelli D, SM Sievert, M Hügler, S Markert, D Becher, T Schweder and C Vetriani. 2017. Insight into the evolution of microbial metabolism from the deep-branching bacterium, Thermovibrio ammonificans. eLife 6: e18990. 10.7554/eLife.18990
